Visualize Temporal Segment Evolution

Source: R/temporal_plotting.R
plot_temporal_segments.Rd

Creates various visualizations for temporal clustering results, including alluvial diagrams, heatmaps, and timeline plots showing how segments evolve over time.

Usage

plot_temporal_segments(
  temporal_result,
  type = "alluvial",
  min_flow = 0.05,
  color_scheme = "default",
  show_labels = TRUE,
  title = NULL,
  ...
)

Arguments

temporal_result

A moneca_temporal object or temporal_stability object.

type

Character string specifying the plot type:

  • "alluvial": Alluvial/Sankey diagram of segment transitions

  • "heatmap": Heatmap of transition probabilities

  • "timeline": Timeline showing segment sizes over time

  • "stability": Stability metrics over time

min_flow

Minimum flow proportion to display in alluvial diagram. Default is 0.05.

color_scheme

Character string specifying color scheme: "default", "viridis", "RdYlBu", or "Set3". Default is "default".

show_labels

Logical indicating whether to show segment labels. Default is TRUE.

title

Character string for plot title. If NULL, auto-generated based on type.

...

Additional arguments passed to plotting functions.

Value

A ggplot2 object that can be further customized or saved.

Details

The function creates different visualizations based on the selected type:

Alluvial diagram: Shows flow of nodes between segments across time windows. Wider ribbons indicate more nodes following that transition path.

Heatmap: Displays the transition probability matrix with color intensity representing transition likelihood.

Timeline: Line plot showing how segment sizes change over time, useful for identifying growing, shrinking, or stable segments.

Stability: Multiple panels showing stability metrics evolution including overall stability, number of active segments, and change magnitudes.

See also

moneca_temporal for temporal clustering, temporal_stability_analysis for stability metrics

Examples

if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{
# Generate and analyze temporal data
months_data <- lapply(1:12, function(m) {
  generate_mobility_data(n_classes = 6, seed = m * 100)
})

temporal_result <- moneca_temporal(months_data, window_size = 3)
stability <- temporal_stability_analysis(temporal_result)

# Create alluvial diagram
plot_temporal_segments(temporal_result, type = "alluvial")

# Create heatmap of transitions
plot_temporal_segments(temporal_result, type = "heatmap")

# Show timeline of segment sizes
plot_temporal_segments(temporal_result, type = "timeline")

# Plot stability metrics
plot_temporal_segments(stability, type = "stability")
} # }
